state.note: Rufus (2), Senpetesth (1) and Panibecis (1) Senpeamus (1)’s father

person.note: For this abbreviated version see Introduction 2.6 and 2.3.1.

Even though these ostraca date to after 117 CE, CPJdecided they belong to a Jewish family who returned to Edfu and assimilated into the population. The identification is based on 1. The name Rufus in the family, which was also found in a prominent Jewish family before 117 CE (See Rufus [1] [L/M]), but this is not decisive, see Introduction 6.1.5.2; 2. The mention in CPJ378 of a certain slave-owner, with the biblical name Sarah, as in earlier Edfu ostraca (see Sarah [4-5]). However, the name Sarah here is reconstructed (Σάρ[ρας]) and even if correct, there are problems with the Jewishness of the name Sarah, see Introduction 6.6.4.1. And see also CPJ 2, p. 118.
The ostraca are dated.
In Greek – προστάντων (presiding).
This is a synagogue inscription, mentioning a προσευχῆς, see Introduction 6.4.1.2.1.
These are the dates of Cleopatra III mentioned in the inscription.
Paid a certain Jewish tax (in Greek – ̓Ιουδαϊκ), see Introduction 6.1.5.
The papyrus is dated.
For this abbreviated version see Introduction 2.6 and 2.3.1.
His daughter paid the Jewish tax, see Introduction 6.1.5.1.
The ostracon is dated.
Included in CPJ only because it was found with Jewish ostraca in the “Jewish quarter” of Edfu, see Introduction 6.1.5.2.
The ostracon is dated.
In Greek – ἀπελεύθ.
Paid the Jewish tax, see Introduction 6.1.5.
The ostraca are dated.

Perhaps CPJ thought he was the owner of Quintus (1), and thus Jewish, but there is no indication for this, see Introduction 6.6.9.2. CPJ may have thought that the man came from the “Jewish quarter” in Edfu, but see Introduction 6.1.5.2.
The ostracon is dated.

Jewishness suggested based on wife’s name, but see under Esther (B/F), n. 1. Also, against any certainty, one may add that the papyrus is late and is not clear about the relationship between Apeitheon and Esther.

Jewishness depends on archaeological find spot – together with CIJ 739, which is certainly Jewish, since it mentions the Hebrew word שלום, see Introduction 6.2. Yet, this person need not be Jewish, since the connection is merely circumstantial, see Introduction 6.5.9.

This tomb is occupied by a family whose names are repeated over the generations. A genealogical reconstruction may suggest that the patriarch of the tomb was Judah, see Introduction 6.5.5.

In Greek – ζήσαντι ἔτη ιζ’ ἡμέρας δ’ (=17 years and 4 days).

There is some confusion about the various publications of this inscription. In one of them the typically Jewish formula ἐν ἰρή(νη)ἡ κοίμησίς σου (in peace his rest) is found, in which case the inscription is probably Jewish, see Introduction 6.10.3.5. But it may not be found in the inscription

Some persons in this papyrus have biblical names, which suggested to the editor that “The whole nomenclature betrays persons of Jewish extraction,” but this is the Christian era, and they could be Christian. The Coptic subscription particularly suggests this, see Introduction 6.6.7.

In Greek – τῶν τριῶν Περσῶν τῆς ἐπιγονῆς (all three Persians of the epigone). For evidence that this term means “debtor” see CPJ1, p. 51, n. 10, and PC 29 (2001) pp. 98-9, n. 14.
Jewishness indicated by father’s name, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
The papyrus is dated.

Even though these ostraca date to after 117 CE, CPJdecided they belong to a Jewish family who returned to Edfu and assimilated into the population, see Introduction 6.1.5.2. The identification is based on 1. The name Rufus in the family, which was also found in a prominent Jewish family before 117 CE (see Rufus [1]), but this is not decisive; 2. The mention in CPJ378 of a certain slave-owner, with the biblical name Sarah, as in earlier Edfu ostraca (see Sarah [5]). However, the name Sarah here is reconstructed (Σάρ[ρας]) and even if correct, there are problems with the Jewishness of the name, see Introduction 6.6.4. And see also CPJ 2, p. 118.
The ostraca are dated.

person.note: Described in the text as ̓Ιουδαίου (Jew), see Introduction 6.1.1.2.
The papyrus is dated to either of these years.
Jewishness may be suggested based on wife’s name, but see Introduction 6.6.6.
The papyrus is dated.
Described with his family members in the papyrus as οἱ τρῖς ̓Ιουδαῖοι (all three Jews) Πέρσαι τῆς ἐπιγονῆς (Persians of the epigone), see Introduction 6.1.1.2.
The papyrus is dated.
For this abbreviated version see Introduction 2.6 and 2.3.1.
His son is described in the text as ̓Ιουδ (Jew), see Introduction 6.1.4.
On inscriptions from Leontopolis and Demerdesh, see Introduction 6.5.1.
The inscription is dated.

note.ref: See above, n. 6. On inscriptions from Leontopolis and Demerdesh, see Introduction 6.5.1.

person.note: The inscription is dated.
See Introduction 2.6.1. On the א suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2, pp. 25-6.
The document is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.1. However, this is a list of names, none of them strictly Jewish.
On inscriptions from Leontopolis see Introduction 6.5.1.
The additional μ is a scribal error, see Introduction 2.8.1. On the fall of the suffix see Introduction 2.6 and 2.3.1.
Jewishness may be suggested based on daughter-in-law’s name (Shabtit [11]), but see Introduction 6.6.6.
The papyrus is dated.
Jewishness may be suggested based on mother’s name, but see Introduction 6.6.6.
The papyrus is dated.
This nominative suffix assumes a different declension.
Jewishness suggested based on son’s name, see Introduction 6.5.1. But this inscription includes mention of Hadas in it, see Introduction 6.10.2.
This name derives from the same root as the one indicated in the title. The suffix, however, is completely different, and see Introduction 2.8.5.
Jewishness suggested based on daughter’s name, but see Introduction 6.6.4.
Jewishness indicated by father’s name, see under Honi (S-H/M), n. 1.
The papyrus is dated.
This inscription comes from the Jewish cemetery of Leontopolis, see Introduction 6.5.1. Jewishness indicated by son’s name, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
Jewishness is suggested based on son’s name, but see Introduction 6.6.6.
The papyrus is dated.
For this abbreviated version see Introduction 2.6 and 2.3.1.
Jewishness may be suggested based on daughter-in-law’s name (Shabtit [16]), but see Introduction 6.6.6.
The papyri are dated.
This nominative suffix assumes a different declension.
Jewishness may be suggested based on mother’s name (Shabtit [16]), but see Introduction 6.6.6.
The papyrus is dated.
Jewishness indicated by his supposed family relationship to persons who had paid the Jewish tax, see CPJ 2, p. 117, but see Introduction 6.1.5.2.
The ostracon is dated.
It has been suggested by Fikhman, SCI 15 (1996) 226, that this papyrus is associated with Jews. I assume he means those with biblical names, but see Introduction 6.6.4 and 6.6.3.
These are the dates of the emperor Heraclius mentioned in the papyrus.
This a variant of the same name, see Foraboschi, ibid.
On inscriptions from Leontopolis and Demerdesh, see Introduction 6.5.1.
The inscription is dated.
In Greek – δοῦλ.
Jewishness suggested based on vicinity to persons with biblical names mentioned in the same document, but see Introduction 6.6.9.2.

This papyrus was not published in full. It suggests that his daughter, described in the papyrus as τῶν ἀπ ’ ̓Οξ(υρύγχων) πόλ(εως) ̓Ιουδαίων (of the Jews of the city of Oxyrhynchus), bought a house in the same Jewish quarter (̓Ιουδακ), see Introduction 6.1.4.
The papyrus is dated.
In Greek – ὡς ἐτῶν τεσεράκοντα πέντε.
On inscription is from the Jewish cemetery of Leontopolis, see Introduction 6.5.1.
The inscription is dated.
According to CPJ2, 117, he is part of a Jewish family, but that is not necessary, see Introduction 6.1.5.2.
The ostraca are dated.
Paid the Jewish tax, see Introduction 6.1.5.
The papyrus is dated.
Jewishness suggested based on father’s name, but he is late, and so may also be Christian, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
This accusative suffix assumes a different declension.
Jewishness is suggested based on relative’s name (Shabtit [9]), but see Introduction 6.6.6.
The papyrus is dated.
Jewishness may be suggested based on mother’s name, but see Introduction 6.6.6.
The papyrus is dated.
For this abbreviated version see Introduction 2.6 and 2.3.1.
Jewishness indicated by father’s name, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.

note.ref: See above, n. 12. For this abbreviated version see Introduction 2.6 and 2.3.1.

person.note: Jewishness suggested based on other names found in the papyrus, but see Introduction 6.6.9.2.

note.ref: See above, n. 12. For this abbreviated version see Introduction 2.6 and 2.3.1.
See above, n. 15. Jewishness suggested based on other names found in the papyrus, but see Introduction 6.6.9.2.

person.note: The suffix, is a scribal error, see Introduction 2.8.5.
Jewishness suggested based on father’s name, but see Introduction 6.6.6.
The papyrus is dated.
CPJ only included this because the ostracon was found together with other Jewish ostraca, in the “Jewish quarter” of Edfu, but see Introduction 6.1.5.2.
The ostracon is dated.
So in CPJ 186.
Paid the Jewish tax, see Introduction 6.1.5.
The ostraca are dated.
Jewishness may be suggested based on father’s name, but see Introduction 6.6.6.
Papyrus CPJ481b is dated.
This ostracon consists of a list of names. Because one of them (Joshua [3]) is Jewish, the editors considered them all so, but see Introduction 6.6.9.2.
This does not look like the same name, but it does include the same consonants, is dissimilar to any other name and was found on a document in Egypt.
Jewishness indicated by son’s name, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
This genitive suffix assumes a different declension (Σαμβᾶς).
Jewishness suggested by Clarysse, “Jews in Trokomia,” 194, based on son’s name, but see under Elijah (B/M) n. 1.
This nominative suffix assumes a different declension.
Jewishness suggested by editor, because of father’s name, but see under Dositheus (G/M), n. 1.
Jewishness suggested based on vicinity to persons with biblical names mentioned in the same document, but see Introduction 6.6.9.2.
Described in the papyrus as Σαμαρίτη[ς], see Introduction 6.1.6.4.
Jewishness suggested based on other names found in the papyrus, but see Introduction 6.6.9.2.
Obviously this genetiv suffix assumes a different declension (Σαμβαίος).
Jewishness indicated by son’s name, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
The inscription is dated.
See Introduction 2.1, and see above, n. 7. This nominative suffix assumes a different declension.
This is a manumission inscription but the word that describes him has not survived.
In Russia, on the north-eastern coast of the Black Sea.

There is nothing Jewish in this inscription except its typological similarity to other manumission inscriptions from the region, where the manumission was performed in the synagogue of the Jews, see Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.3, and Gibson, Jewish Manumission Inscriptions, 150-2.
Jewishness may be suggested based on wife’s name, but see Introduction 6.6.6.
The papyrus is dated.
Jewishness may be suggested based on wife’s name, but see Introduction 6.6.6.

note.ref: See above, n. 3. The papyrus is dated.

person.note: CPJ suggested that all persons listed in this papyrus are Jews, because some of them have biblical names, but see Introduction 6.6.9.2; and they come from the village of Samaria, but see Introduction 6.1.6.4.1.
The papyrus is dated to one of these years.

Even though these ostraca date to after 117 CE, CPJdecided they belong to a Jewish family who returned to Edfu and assimilated into the population, see Introduction 6.1.5.2. The identification is based on 1. The name Rufus in the family, which was also found in a prominent Jewish family before 117 CE (see Rufus no. [1]), but this is not decisive; 2. The mention in CPJ378 of a certain slave-owner, with the biblical name Sarah, as in earlier Edfu ostraca (see Sarah [4-5]). However, the name Sarah here is reconstructed (Σάρ[ρας]) and even if correct, there are problems with the Jewishness of the name, see Introduction 6.6.4.1. And see also CPJ 2, p. 118.
The ostraca are dated.
For this abbreviated version see Introduction 2.6 and 2.3.1.

Even though these ostraca date to after 117 CE, CPJdecided they belong to a Jewish family who returned to Edfu and assimilated into the population, see Introduction 6.1.5.2. The identification is based on 1. The name Rufus in the family, which was also found in a prominent Jewish family before 117 CE (see Rufus [1] [L/M]), but this is not decisive; 2. The mention in CPJ378 of a certain slave-owner, with the biblical name Sarah, as in earlier Edfu ostraca (see Sarah [5]). However, the name Sarah here is reconstructed (Σάρ[ρας]) and even if correct, there are problems with the Jewishness of the name, see Introduction 6.6.4.1. And see also CPJ 2, p. 118.
The ostraca are dated.
Jewishness suggested based on daughter’s name, but it is not recorded elsewhere as a Hebrew name in Egypt, see Introdcution 6.6.3, and her father’s name is Egyptian.
The papyrus is dated.
Described in the papyrus as ̓Ιουδαίου (Jew), see Introduction 6.1.1.2.
The papyrus is dated.
Jewishness may be suggested based on mother’s name, but see Introduction 6.6.6.
The papyrus is dated.
Jewishness suggested based on the fact that the inscription mentions that his relative is a Sabbatarai, but see Introduction 6.4.1.2.3.
This seems to be the same name, with another, Greek nominative suffix, see Introduction 2.4.2.2.1.
In Latin – Ebraicus Omirus (the Hebrew Homer).
Described in the text as Ebraicus (Hebrew), see Introduction 6.1.2.
The text is dated.
His son is described in the text as ̓Ιουδαίῳ τὴν θρησκείαν (a Jew by religion), see Introduction 6.1.4.
The papyrus is dated.
On inscriptions from Leontopolis see Introduction 6.5.1.
The inscription is dated.
Jewishness may be suggested based on his grandmother’s name Shabtit (10), but see Introduction 6.6.6.
The papyrus is dated.
For this abbreviated version see Introduction 2.6 and 2.3.1.
Jewishness may be suggested based on daughter-in-law’s name (Shabtit [15]), but see Introduction 6.6.6.
The papyrus is dated.
The additional ε is probably a scribal error, see Introduction 2.8.1.
In Greek – ὡς β’.
On inscriptions from Leontopolis see Introduction 6.5.1.
The inscription is dated.
This ostracon describes a feast presided over by a Jewish priest (Joseph [13]). Since it makes sense that this is a Jewish feast, I considered all participants Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
Paid the Jewish tax, see Introduction 6.1.5.
The ostraca are dated.
Jewishness assumed based on provenance in the “Jewish Quarter“ of Edfu, but see Introduction 6.1.5.2.
The ostracon is dated, but the reading of the date on it is not clear.

note.ref: See above, n. 5. Jewishness assumed based on provenance in the “Jewish Quarter“ of Edfu, but see Introduction 6.1.5.2.
See above, n. 6. The ostracon is dated, but the reading of the date on it is not clear.

person.note: See Introduction 2.1.
Jewishness suggested based on his presence on an ostracon with biblical names from the “Jewish quarter” of Edfu, but see Introduction 6.1.5.2.
For the abbreviation see Introduction 2.3.1.
Jewishness indicated by first name, see Introduction 6.6.
The papyrus is dated.
Described in the papyrus as ̓Ιουδαῖος (Jew), see Introduction 6.1.1.5.
The papyrus is dated.

note.ref: See above, n. 11. For the abbreviation see Introduction 2.3.1.

person.note: Jewishness indicated by father’s name, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
In Greek – ἐτελεύτησε ἐτῶν ν’.
The inscription was acquired in Gizeh. Provenance unknown.
Early editors thought he was Jewish because they believed the inscription originated from Leontopolis, but see Introduction 6.5.1,and there is no evidence for this premise.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed.
For this form as an alternative nominative declension, see Introduction 2.3.
In Greek – ὡς ε’.
The inscription is found in Rome today, but is typical of inscriptions from Leontopolis.
On inscriptions from Leontopolis see Introduction 6.5.1.
See Introduction 2.6.1. The form is undeclined.
The document is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.1. This is a list of mostly biblical names, so I consider them all Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
See above, n. 2. See Introduction 2.6.1. The form is undeclined. If this is indeed the same name, the ו and ר may be scribal errors, see Introduction 2.8.1.
In Aramaic – ואנושה.

note.ref: See above, n. 3. The document is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.1. This is a list of mostly biblical names, so I consider them all Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.

person.note: The ostracon was found in the “Jewish quarter” of Edfu, but see Introduction 6.1.5.2.
Jewishness may be suggested based on son-in-law’s grandfather’s name (Shabtai [52]), but see Introduction 6.6.6.
The papyrus is dated.
The fall of the υ is obviously a scribal error, see Introduction 2.8.2.
Jewishness may be suggested based on great, great grandfather’s name (Shabtai [52]), but see Introduction 6.6.6.
The papyrus is dated.
This nominative suffix assumes a different declension.

The papyrus is both very Jewish in character, including such expressions as ̓Αδωναὶ ̓Ελο[αὶ Σα ]βαώθ = אדוני אלהי צבאות, and Jewish angel names, but see Introduction 6.10.1.6. The mother’s name was also interpreted as Jewish, but see Introduction 6.6.4.1.
On this alternative suffix see Introduction 2.6 and 2.3.3.7.
Found in a Jewish catacomb, see Introduction 6.5.3.
This reading is in JIWE 1, 40. CIJread “Felix” tentatively. On the single consonant see Introduction 2.6 and 2.3.3.4. The declension is probably a scribal error, see Introduction 2.8.3.
Deascribed on the amphorae as ̓Ιουδαΐκος (Judaean; Jew), see Introduction 6.1.1.5.
The destruction of Pompeii through the eruption of the Mount Vesuvius occurred in this year.
Paid the Jewish tax, see Introduction 6.1.5.
The ostraca are dated.

div.note: The name ̓Αχιλλᾶς appears in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 69. It is obviously an Egyptian abbreviation of the Greek name Achilleus, see Introduction 1.5.1.
The name ̓Αχιλλίων appears in papyri, see Foraboschi, Namenbuch, 76. It is obviously an Egyptian abbreviation of the Greek name Achilleus, see Introduction 1.5.1.
The name ̓Ακιᾶρις appears in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 15; Foraboschi, Namenbuch, 23.
The name ̓Ακιῆς appears in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 15.
The name ̓Ακυντᾶς appears in papyri, see Foraboschi, Namenbuch, 24.
The name ̓Αμάρων appears in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 22; Foraboschi, Namenbuch, 27.
Common Egyptian name, appears often in papyri (̓Αγχῶφις/̓Αγχοῦφις), see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 8.
Probably an Egyptian name. Appears on papyri (̓Αγγίων), see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 6; Foraboschi, Namenbuch, 18.

Although I have not found this name recorded elsewhere, it is clearly a Greek name, with the theophoric element – θεός. It may mean Apis (the Egyptian bull-god) being God, see Introduction 1.2.3 and 1.5.1.
The name ̓Αφύγχις appears in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 68.
The name ̓Αργαῖος appears in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 45, Foraboschi, Namenbuch, 46.
WGE, 139, records ̓Αρμαῖος as the Hellenized version of an Egyptian king’s name.
The name ̔Αρφαῆσις appears in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 58.
The name ̓Αρσείων appears in papyri, see Foraboschi, Namenbuch, 53.
The name ̓Αρσοῦς appears in papyri, see Foraboschi, Namenbuch, 54.

This name (̓Αρθώτης) and others similar to it (̓Αρθοῶνις, ̓Αρθώθης, ̓Αρθώιος, ̓Αρθῶνις, ̓Αρθώυθης, ̓Αρθώυτης) are common Egyptian names, that appear often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 47.
The name Βησᾶς appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 74, Foraboschi, Namenbuch, 80. It is probably derived from the Egyptian God Bes, see Introduction 1.5.2.

According to WGE 591 Καίμις is another name for the Egyptian God Horus. Various forms of the name (Καίμιος / Καῖμος / Καιμῆς /Καιμίων) are mentioned on papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 157, Foraboschi, Namenbuch, 155.
The name Κᾶνις appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 164; Foraboschi, Namenbuch, 159.
The names Καπαι, Καπῆς, and Καπῖς appear often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 165.
The names Καροῦρ and Καροῦρις appear often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 166.
The name Κέννις appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 171.
The name Κεφαλᾶς appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 172. It is obviously an Egyptian abbreviation of the Greek name Caphalion, see Introduction 1.5.1
The name Κεφάλων appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 172-3. It is obviously an Egyptian variation on the Greek name Caphalion, see Introduction 1.5.1.
The name Διογᾶς appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 88. It is obviously an Egyptian abbreviation of the Greek name Diogenes, see Introduction 1.5.1.
Egyptian name (Δωσαρίων), appears in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 94.

The name Δωσᾶς appears often in papyri, see Foraboschi, Namenbuch, 101. LGPN 1, 145, also mentions this name but there it refers only to people in the Egyptian sphere of influence (Cyrenaica and Rhodes). It is obviously an Egyptian abbreviation of the Greek name Dositheus, see Introduction 1.5.1.
The name Δόσθων appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 93. It is obviously an Egyptian variation of the Greek name Dositheus, see Introduction 1.5.1.
The name, according to JIWE 1, 623, is derived from the Egyptian goddess Isis, see Introduction 1.2.3. For similar names (Εἰσαρεῦς; Εἰσάριον; Εἰσαροῦς) see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 96.
The name ̓Εσοῦρις appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 109.
The name Γενναῖος appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 80.
Common Egyptian name, appears often in papyri (̔Αροβρῶς / ̔Αροβρωοῦς), see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 52.
Common Egyptian name, appears often in papyri (̔Αρπαῆσις / ̔Αρφαῆσις), see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 53, 58.
Common Egyptian name, appears often in papyri (̔Αρπαγάθης), see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 52.
The name ̔́Αρπαλος appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 53.
The name ̔Αρπαμοῦς is recorded on a papyrus, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 53.
The name ̔Ατρῆς appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 53.
The name appears in papyri, see Foraboschi, Namenbuch, 144.
The name ̔Ωρος appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 497. It is derived from the Egyptian God Horus, see Introduction 1.5.2.
The name ̓Ιναρόους appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 149.

This name is probably Egyptian, although it is not recorded in other papyri, because it is recorded in Egypt both in Hebrew and in Greek letters, but is recorded neither in the Bible nor in other Semitic texts, nor is it Greek (and the dates of the documents rule out a Latin provenance).
The name Λοβόϊς appears in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 191.
The name Λολοῦς appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 198.
The name Λυσᾶς appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 200; Foraboschi, Namenbuch, 184. It is obviously an Egyptian abbreviation of the Greek name Lysanias, see Introduction 1.5.1.

Marius is obviously a Latin gentilium, see RNGCL, 113. However, it is unlikely that a Jew (or a non-Jew) in the second century BCE in Egypt would have borne a Latin name. For the name Μάριος in Egyptian papyri see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 206, and Foraboschi, Namenbuch, 188.
The name Μεθυσίων appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 211.
The name Μῶρος appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 223.
The name Μυσθᾶς appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 222.
Egyptian names with the prefix Ναφερ and Νεφερ are common, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 225, 230-1.
WGE, 984, records this name (Νειλάμμων), but states that it is Egyptian. It is recorded often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 227.
WGE, 984-5, records this name (Νεῖλος) as the name of the river Nile. It is also recorded often as a personal name in Egypt, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 227.
The name Νέων appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 232.
The name ̓Ορσενοῦφις appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 244.
The name Πά appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 250.
The name Πααβῶς appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 250; Foraboschi, Namenbuch, 222.
The name Πάκκιος appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 257.
The name Πᾶχις appears in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 294.
The name Παχούμιος / Παχύμιος appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 296.
The name Παχράτης appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 296.
The name Πακῦσις appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 259.
The name Παΐῶν appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 257.
The name Παμούνιος appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 264.
The name Πανεσνεῦς appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 267.
The name Πανετβήουϊς appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 267.
Egyptian names beginning with πενιβ are recorded, see WGE, 1125, and Preisigke, Namenbuch, 269, but not this one.
The name Παοῦς appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 274.
The name Παποντῶς appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 277.
The name Πασχεῖς appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 284, Foraboschi, Namenbuch, 238.
The name Πᾶσις appears in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 282.
The name Πατκῶς appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 288.
The name Πατεπός appears in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 286.
The name Πατῆς appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 287.
The name Πατευρῖς appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 287.
The name Παθρῆς/Φαθρῆς appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 256, 453.
The name Πεκμέις appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 301.
The name Περῆτ appears occasionally in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 306.
This is the only person under this name documented by Preisigke, Namenbuch, 307, but it also records other Egyptian names with the prefix περτ.
The name Πεσοῦρ appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 308.
The name Πεταυ῁ος appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 310.
The name Πετερμοῦθις appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 315.
The name Πετεσοῦχος appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 316.
The name Πεθεῦς appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 300.
The name Πέτων appears often in papyri, see Foraboschi, Namenbuch, 257.
Πετορ is recorded as an Egyptian name, see WGE, 1186. Many names with this prefix are recorded on papyri ,see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 319, but not this one.
The name Πετῶς appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 322.
The name Φᾶβις/Φάβεις appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 452.
The name Φαῆρις appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 452.
The name φαῆσις appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 451.
The name Φαμῆς appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 454, Foraboschi, Namenbuch, 326.
The name φιβίων appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 461.
The name Φομοῦνις is recorded once in another papyrus, see Foraboschi, Namenbuch, 336.
The name Πινᾶς appears in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 326, although it is probably a reference to this person. Preisigke, Namenbuch, 265, thinks this refers to the Egyptian name Πανᾶς.
The name Πνεφερῶς appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 334-5.
Many Egyptian names with the prefix Ψιare recorded on papyri (see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 493-4) but not this one.
The name Ψιμανῶβετ appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 493.
The name Ψονσναῦς appears in papyri, see Foraboschi, Namenbuch, 349.
Egyptian names with the prefix Ψοσ and Ψωσ are common, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 494-5.
The name Ψούβιος appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 494.
Many Egyptian names with the prefix πτεare recorded on papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 348, but not this one.
The name Πτολλᾶς appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 349. It is obviously an Egyptian abbreviation of the Greek name Ptolemaius, see Introduction 1.5.1.
The name Πτολλίων appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 350. It is obviously an Egyptian abbreviation of the Greek name Ptolemaius, see Introduction 1.5.1.
The name Πτολλις appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 349-50. It is obviously an Egyptian abbreviation of the Greek name Ptolemaius, see Introduction 1.5.1.
The name Σαμβα appears often on Egyptian papyri, see Foraboschi, Namenbuch, 278. Preisigke, Namenbuch, 360, records the form .Σαμβᾶς.
Common Egyptian name (Σαταβοῦς), appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 365.
Many Egyptian names with the prefix Σενεare recorded on papyri (see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 371-2-4) but not this one.
Names with the Egyptian element Σενπε are very common on papyri. Preisigke, Namenbuch, 375 records the form Σενπεμαοῦς.
Names with the Egyptian element Σενπε are very common on papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 374-5.
The name Σενθέως appears on Egyptian papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 372.
The name Σεῶς appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 482.
The name Σισόϊς appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 386.
The name Σωσᾶς appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 400.
Common Egyptian name (Σουροῦς), appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 392.
Common Egyptian name, (Στοήτις) appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 395.
Τεώς is the name of an Egyptian king, see WGE, 1514. And see also Preisigke, Namenbuch, 433.
Many Egyptian names have the prefix Τετ, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 431.

The name Τεύφιλος appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 432. It is obviously an Egyptian version of the Greek Θεόφιλος, but this version is recorded only in Egypt, see Introduction 1.5.1.
The name Θανοῦφις appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 128.
The name Θατρῆς appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 129.
The name Τιθοῆς / Τιθωῆς appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 435.
The name Τοθῆς appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 442.
The name Τρύλλος appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 445.
The name Τρυφᾶς appears often in papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 446. It is obviously an Egyptian abbreviation of the Greek name Τρύφων, see Introduction 1.5.1.
